Name: Adjust Balance Amount
Summary: Guide for Adjust Balance Amount
Body:
In this article, you'll learn how to adjust a patient's paid amount to any other date of service.

Step 1: Select the patient whose balance you want to adjust. To do this, go to Patients and select the desired patient.

Step 2: View the patient's profile.

Step 3: Navigate to the Billing tab on the left scroll.

Step 4: Here, you'll see all the charge IDs for that patient. If a patient payment is available or the patient has paid any amount, the Adjust Balance button will be available. However, if the charge ID is in closed status, you won't be able to move or adjust that balance to any other date of service. To adjust the balance, click on the Add this balance button.

Step 5: You'll now see all dates of services for that patient. You can adjust the balance with these dates of service.

Step 6: For instance, let's say you're adjusting from the patient's date of service on the 29th of February 2024, and for that particular charge ID, the patient has paid $310. You can adjust a partial or full amount to any date of service listed in the table.

Step 7: As an example, let's adjust $10 to this charge ID for a $100 tourist charge ID.

Step 8: Once you click out of the box, you'll see the total remaining balance, which you can adjust to any other date of services.

Step 9: Once the total amount is adjusted, you won't be able to adjust any more balances. The button will be disabled and you'll see that the remaining amount is going to credit balance.

Step 10: When you're done, click on the Adjust Balance button. The system will automatically adjust these balances to all the charge IDs for which you were adjusting the balances.

Step 11: You can track the payment details under the charge ID that you just set this balance for.

Step 12: To see the payment details, go to Detail View and move to the Payments tab.

Step 13: Here, you'll see the payment from charge ID 911-3295 and the date of service using which we have adjusted a $200 in discharge ID.

Thank you for following this tutorial.

Name: Billing Dashboard Overview
Summary: Guide for Billing Dashboard Overview
Body:
Explore the Spry billing dashboard and its features. This guide provides a detailed walkthrough of the dashboard, its sections, and functionalities.Start by accessing the billing dashboard. On the left-hand side, click on the money sign labeled Billing.

Step 1: Familiarize with the dashboard layout. Notice the different sections at the top: overall billing tab, patient collection tab, reports, and the newly added reports section. These provide a comprehensive overview of the clinic and detailed reports.

Step 2: Use the filters. Filter data by payer name, PP, tags, patient names, charge ID, claim statuses, or set a date range. For this guide, leave these filters empty.

Step 3: Understand the claim buckets. The dashboard displays different buckets where claims can sit. The first one is Draft.

Step 4: Explore the Draft section. This is where claims are prepared before submission. Here, view all claims ready for submission, make edits or changes as needed, update the overall status, submit the claim, write it off, or edit it.

Step 5: Edit a claim. Clicking on edit takes into the actual claim. Click on the edit button at the top.

Step 6: Edit details such as the ICD code or the CPT code. Ensure these are correct before sending them out. Once done, click on done to save changes.

Step 7: To save the changes. Click on save.

Step 8: Return to the dashboard. Click on Draft again. If desired, submit the claim.

Step 9: Understand the Accepted bucket. These are claims that have been accepted by the clearinghouse. Once paid by the insurance payer, they move to the Bill Pending section.

Step 10: Understand the bill pending section. This is where the patient responsibility lies. Once the patient pays their portion, closing the claim, it moves to the Close section.

Step 11: Understand the paper submission buckets. Some payers require a paper submission. These claims are tracked in the Paper Submission and Paper Submitted sections.

Step 12: Understand the Rejected bucket. These are claims that have been rejected by the clearinghouse. The reasons for rejection are provided for review and correction before resubmission.

Step 13: Understand the Pending Review section. This is where claims with partial payments are reviewed to ensure full payment.

Step 14: Understand the Denied section. These are claims denied by the payer, not the clearinghouse. The reasons for denial are provided.

Step 15: Edit a denied claim. Make necessary changes and resubmit the claim.

Step 16: Understand the Self Pay bucket. This is where all self pay claims are tracked.

Step 17: Export data. All data can be exported for further analysis or record-keeping.

Name: Missed Copay Feature
Summary: Guide for Missed Copay Feature
Body: This guide explains how to use the "Missed Copay" feature in the Billing tab and the significance of the red and green dollar icons on the scheduler. The scheduler displays two appointments for the therapist, Megan Young. The patient, Ross Helms, has a red dollar sign next to his appointment. This red dollar sign indicates that the copay has been entered in the total copay field, but it hasn't been collected yet. On the other hand, the patient, Courtney Butler, has a green dollar sign next to her appointment. This green dollar sign signifies that the copay has been collected. For instance, Courtney's copay is twenty dollars, and the collected amount is also twenty dollars. Hence, a collected copay is represented by a green dollar sign. Now, let's consider a scenario where a patient has a copay of thirty dollars, but it was missed during collection. To rectify this, navigate to the patient's timeline. Then, proceed to the Billing tab. Here, we've added a "Missed Copay" feature. It shows a missed copay amount of thirty dollars that needs to be collected from the patient. To collect this payment, click on "Collect Payments". If there are multiple missed copays, select the relevant charge IDs. All copays will be listed in the columns. After selecting the charge IDs for which payment needs to be collected, click on "Collect Payment". This allows you to collect the payment from the patient using different payment methods. After choosing the payment method, click on the "Collect Payment" option. If you need to send an invoice to the patient for the missed copay, there's an option in the total outstanding balance called "Collect Payments". Click on it. The missed copay invoice will appear on the left screen panel. To send the invoice to the patient, click on "List Copay List".

Name: Refunds & Move Balance to E-wallet
Summary: Guide for Refunds & Move Balance to E-wallet
Body:
In this article, you'll learn how to process refunds on Spry, a feature useful for front desk staff or administrators.

Step 1: Start by selecting a patient whose charges you want to refund. Navigate to the billing screen. Here, you'll see a list of charge IDs for various services.

Step 2: To refund charges for a specific service, locate the refund button next to the service.

Step 3: Clicking the refund button reveals all information related to that particular charge ID, including past transactions, transaction methods, and any refunds previously processed.

Step 4: Let's assume a transaction occurred on this charge ID on April 16th and the patient paid $25. Now, you need to refund an amount. Enter the amount you wish to refund.

Step 5: After entering the amount, select a reason for the refund.

Step 6: By default, the refund processes using the same method as the original transaction. Click on Refund to finalize the process.

Step 7: You'll notice that the amount has been successfully refunded. Now, if you want to transfer this balance to the E Wallet instead of a refund, select a specific transaction. For example, if you want to move $10 to the eWallet, choose the move to eWallet option.

Step 8: After selecting the move to eWallet option, select a reason and click on refund to eWallet.

Step 9: The specific transaction moves to the eWallet, updating the balance accordingly.

Step 10: You can view all the refund history, including the total number of refunds processed to date and the refund transactions, in the refund history section.

And that's it! You've successfully processed a refund on Spry.

This guide explains how to access and use Scribe Ally from your Electronic Medical Record (EMR). Scribe Ally is a tool that allows you to dictate or record conversations with patients, which it then transcribes and fills into your documentation template.Accessing Scribe Ally

Step 1: Locate the Scribe Ally icon within the documentation template in your EMR.

Step 2: Click on the Scribe Ally icon.Using Scribe Ally

Step 3: Choose to dictate a quick note or record the full conversation with your patient.

Step 4: Click on the 'Start Recording' option.

Step 5: For this guide, a transcript of a patient-provider conversation has been uploaded. Click 'Stop Recording' once the conversation is complete.

Reviewing the Transcription

Step 7: Review the filled-in details in the 'Subjective' form. Scribe Ally fills in the details per field where applicable.

Step 8: Check the 'Objective' template. It's also filled in per field where applicable.

Step 10: Review the 'Plan' section. Scribe Ally also fills this in based on your preferences.

Remember, the templating in your 'Subjective' and 'Objective' sections is completely customizable. You decide what kinds of fields you want and how you want the output to present.

Logging In

Navigating the Home Screen

Step 2: After logging in, patients encounter a user-friendly home screen that provides quick access to all essential features, facilitating interaction with the clinic.

Scheduling an Appointment

Step 4: They then select the required details such as Clinic Location,Preferred Therapist, Appointment Type, and Payment Method.

Step 5: With just a few taps, their appointment request is created, reducing the administrative workload for clinic staff.

Updating Insurance Information

Step 6: If a patient needs to update their insurance information, they can easily add their insurance card using the smart AI capture feature.

Step 7: By taking a picture of their insurance card, the system automatically captures most of the insurance details, prefilling the information. They just need to review and submit, saving time for everyone.

Updating Personal and Medical Information

Step 8: Keeping personal and medical information current is crucial for providing quality care. Patients have a clear view of their profile submissions, including personal and medical details.

Step 9: If any information is incomplete or needs updating, they can access and edit it anytime before their appointment.

These details remain with them across multiple appointments, ensuring continuity of care. Managing Billing

Step 10: Simplifying billing processes benefits both the patient and the clinic. If a patient has a pending balance to pay, they can handle it swiftly. By going to the Billing tab, they can view their pending amount and pay it upfront with just a few clicks.

This improves cash flow and reduces overdue payments. Completing Intake Forms

Step 11: Enhance efficiency by allowing patients to complete intake forms ahead of time. From their appointment details, they see that their intake is not submitted yet. They can quickly access and complete their paperwork before the appointment.

Step 12: Personal, medical, and insurance information are already filled if previously provided. They proceed directly to subjective

All their paperwork is done ensuring appointments start on time. Viewing Appointments

Step 13: Staying organized helps reduce no shows and missed appointments. Patients can view all their upcoming and completed appointments in one place.

Step 14: By accessing the My Appointment section, they can see their schedule without hassles.

Step 7: Check out the comparison of average self-pay amount and average insurance paid amount. You'll also see reimbursement per appointment types.

Step 8: Look at the therapist collected amount. This is the amount that the therapist has collected.

Step 9: Check out reimbursements per payer. This shows how much reimbursement the clinic has received from a particular payer.

Step 10: Move to account receivable (AR). Here, you can track primary and secondary AR and drill down for more details.

Remember, these reports can be customized on demand. The provider can see their own data, while the clinic's admin or front desk can see the whole clinic's data. That's all about the Spry BI Tool. Thank you for reading!

Name: Client Onboarding via Slack
Summary: Guide for Client Onboarding via Slack
Body:
This article will guide you through the process of using Slack for seamless client onboarding and efficient query resolution.

Step 1: Start by understanding the onboarding process. Once a client is onboarded, we create a group and add the clients to a specific Slack channel. This ensures smooth onboarding.

Step 2: If you have any queries or questions, simply post them on the channel. This way, everyone can assist you with a suitable resolution.

Step 3: To initiate a conversation, simply say "Hi team, kindly resolve the query." Inform us about your issue and the responsible team will take over and help you with a resolution.

Step 4: Ensure not to ask another query on the same thread. If another query is asked on the same thread, there's a chance of missing out on the query. Always start a fresh conversation for each new query.

Step 5: To keep track of your first query and its resolution, check the replies from the team members. This will give you an idea of the progress towards resolving your query. You can raise your second query in the same manner.

Step 6: Remember, using Slack is simple. Whenever a new conversation is initiated, ensure it's not under any other query's thread. It should always be a new conversation.

Step 7: Keep in mind that every new query should initiate a new conversation on Slack.

Step 8: Once satisfied, click Push to SOAP.

Your selected content will instantly fill into your notes. For future use, you have the option to build on an existing Transcript or refine it to further enhance outputs, or start a fresh new one. That's it! With these improvements, Scribe offers smoother navigation, personalized settings, and a review-first process, giving you complete control over your documentation.
